title: 113_s1619
content: The "Skills Gap Strategy Act of 2013" may be cited as the Act. It includes a provision for a strategy report. The Secretary must develop a strategy report for Congress addressing the skills gap by increasing on-the-job training, apprenticeship opportunities, and employer participation in education and workforce training. The report should include recommendations to increase employer and employee participation, enhance Department of Labor outreach to employers, and prioritize nationally portable postsecondary credentials. The Secretary is required to include in the strategy report a comparison of US on-the-job training and apprenticeship policies with other countries, as well as an assessment of the Registered Apprenticeship program to appeal to more industries and boost goals. The Secretary must evaluate opportunities within the Department of Labor to better support on-the-job training and apprenticeship goals, analyze barriers hindering the domestic workforce from acquiring desired skills, and make recommendations to address the skills gap. The Secretary will provide recommendations in the skills gap strategy report to achieve goals, including actions for various entities to improve policies and partnerships, and adopt successful strategies from key industries and regions in the US and other countries. The Secretary, in coordination with other departments, will develop plans to increase employer participation in career and technical education, align curriculums with industry sectors, promote pre-apprenticeship programs, improve school-to-work transitions, and facilitate partnerships with schools and service providers. The Secretary must submit a strategy report within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit a strategy report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary has the authority to implement recommendations as deemed appropriate, if allowed by law. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "industry-recognized" refers to a credential accepted by employers in the industry sector, endorsed by a trade association, and nationally portable. "Recognized postsecondary credential" consists of an industry-recognized credential. The curr_chunk discusses various types of credentials for postsecondary training, including industry-recognized credentials, certificates, apprenticeship completion certificates, and degrees from higher education institutions. It also defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Labor and explains the concept of a "skills gap" in the workforce.
